How do I use the `z_viewémon` command to view a transaction in Verus?

There is no `z_viewémon` command in Verus. The correct command to view a transaction is `z_viewtransaction`. You can use it in the command line, for example: `verus z_viewtransaction "1075db55d416d3ca199f55b6084e2115b9345e16c5cf302fc80e9d5fbf5d48d"`.

Examples:
```bash
> verus z_viewtransaction "1075db55d416d3ca199f55b6084e2115b9345e16c5cf302fc80e9d5fbf5d48d"
> curl --user myusername --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "z_viewtransaction", "params": ["1075db55d416d3ca199f55b6084e2115b9345e16c5cf302fc80e9d5fbf5d48d"] }' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:27486/
```### `zcbenchmark benchmarktype samplecount`
Runs a benchmark of the selected type samplecount times,
returning the running times of each sample.#### Result:
```json
[
 {
  "runningtime": runningtime
 },
 {
  "runningtime": runningtime
 }
 ...
]
```### `zcrawjoinsplit rawtx inputs outputs vpub_old vpub_new`
inputs: a JSON object mapping {note: zcsecretkey, ...}
outputs: a JSON object mapping {zcaddr: value, ...}DEPRECATED. Splices a joinsplit into rawtx. Inputs are unilaterally confidential.
Outputs are confidential between sender/receiver. The vpub_old and vpub_new values are globally public and move transparent value into or out of the confidential value store, respectively.
What is the purpose of the `zcrawjoinsplit` command, and how do I use it?

The `zcrawjoinsplit` command splices a joinsplit into a raw transaction. It requires specific inputs, such as `rawtx`, `inputs`, and `outputs`, as well as `vpub_old` and `vpub_new` values. The inputs are unilaterally confidential, while the outputs are confidential between the sender and receiver.

Examples:
```bash
> verus z_viewtransaction "1075db55d416d3ca199f55b6084e2115b9345e16c5cf302fc80e9d5fbf5d48d"
> curl --user myusername --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "z_viewtransaction", "params": ["1075db55d416d3ca199f55b6084e2115b9345e16c5cf302fc80e9d5fbf5d48d"] }' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:27486/
```### `zcbenchmark benchmarktype samplecount`
Runs a benchmark of the selected type samplecount times,
returning the running times of each sample.#### Result:
```json
[
 {
  "runningtime": runningtime
 },
 {
  "runningtime": runningtime
 }
 ...
]
```### `zcrawjoinsplit rawtx inputs outputs vpub_old vpub_new`
inputs: a JSON object mapping {note: zcsecretkey, ...}
outputs: a JSON object mapping {zcaddr: value, ...}DEPRECATED. Splices a joinsplit into rawtx. Inputs are unilaterally confidential.
Outputs are confidential between sender/receiver. The vpub_old and vpub_new values are globally public and move transparent value into or out of the confidential value store, respectively.
Can you explain how to use the `zcbenchmark` command to benchmark a blockchain network?

The `zcbenchmark` command does not benchmark a blockchain network. It actually runs a benchmark of a selected type a specified number of times, returning the running times of each sample. The correct syntax is `zcbenchmark benchmarktype samplecount`.

Examples:
```bash
> verus z_viewtransaction "1075db55d416d3ca199f55b6084e2115b9345e16c5cf302fc80e9d5fbf5d48d"
> curl --user myusername --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "z_viewtransaction", "params": ["1075db55d416d3ca199f55b6084e2115b9345e16c5cf302fc80e9d5fbf5d48d"] }' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:27486/
```### `zcbenchmark benchmarktype samplecount`
Runs a benchmark of the selected type samplecount times,
returning the running times of each sample.#### Result:
```json
[
 {
  "runningtime": runningtime
 },
 {
  "runningtime": runningtime
 }
 ...
]
```### `zcrawjoinsplit rawtx inputs outputs vpub_old vpub_new`
inputs: a JSON object mapping {note: zcsecretkey, ...}
outputs: a JSON object mapping {zcaddr: value, ...}DEPRECATED. Splices a joinsplit into rawtx. Inputs are unilaterally confidential.
Outputs are confidential between sender/receiver. The vpub_old and vpub_new values are globally public and move transparent value into or out of the confidential value store, respectively.
